choices.text: Administer corticosteroids and await spontaneous labor
Perform intrauterine transfusion under ultrasound guidance

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman with known Rh-negative blood group presents at 32 weeks for routine follow-up. Her first pregnancy was delivered at home, and she did not receive anti-D immunoglobulin postpartum. Current ultrasound shows signs of fetal hydrops: ascites, scalp edema, and placentomegaly. MCA-PSV is 1.7 MoM. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Perform intrauterine transfusion under ultrasound guidance

choices.text: Digital vaginal examination to assess cervical dilation

questions.text: A 33-year-old G3P2 woman at 28 weeks presents with sudden, painless, bright red vaginal bleeding. She has no uterine tenderness or contractions. Fetal heart rate is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Transabdominal and transvaginal ultrasound

choices.text: Beta hCG now and repeat beta-hCG in 48 hours

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and spotting. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. Urine pregnancy test is positive. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterus with a 3 cm adnexal mass and free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. Her vitals show HR 112 bpm, BP 92/60 mmHg. What is the next best step?

choices.text: GDM; Begin medical nutrition therapy and monitor glucose

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, at 28 weeks gestation has a 75 g OGTT with fasting glucose 98 mg/dL, 1-hour 182 mg/dL, and 2-hour 168 mg/dL. She has no prior history of diabetes. What is the correct diagnosis and management plan?
questions.solution: Ans. C) GDM; begin medical nutrition therapy and monitor glucose

choices.text: Antibiotics and elective cystectomy as planned

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of severe right lower quadrant pain and nausea. She has a known 5 cm dermoid cyst in the right ovary for which she was planning an elective laparoscopy in a few months time. On pelvic examination, adnexal tenderness is noted. Ultrasound shows an enlarged right ovary with peripheral follicles and absent Doppler flow. What is the next best step?

A 27-year-old woman presents with infertility for 2 years. She has irregular cycles (35–45 days), acne, and hirsutism. BMI is 32 kg/m². Transvaginal ultrasound shows multiple subcapsular follicles with increased ovarian volume. Her day 2 LH:FSH ratio is 3:1 and prolactin, TSH are normal. She has been taking steps actively to change her lifestyle and optimize her BMI. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 29-year-old nulliparous woman presents with progressively worsening dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia for 1 year. Examination reveals a fixed, retroverted uterus with nodularity in the posterior fornix. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a cyst in the left ovary with ground glass appearance. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Antibiotics, followed by a repeat VIA in 6 months

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman undergoes a VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid) test as part of a camp-based screening. A dense acetowhite lesion is seen near the transformation zone, which persists beyond 1 minute. She is asymptomatic and has never had a Pap smear. What is the most appropriate next step?

A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with watery vaginal discharge and irregular bleeding. On speculum exam, a friable 3 cm growth is seen on the cervix involving the upper vagina. Biopsy confirms moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. MRI pelvis shows parametrial extension but no pelvic wall involvement. What is the FIGO stage and ideal treatment?

A 25-year-old woman presents with 2 first-trimester pregnancy losses. Her cycles are regular, and she has no dysmenorrhea. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a normal external uterine contour with an echogenic fibrous band dividing the endometrial cavity. MRI confirms the diagnosis. What is the next step in management?
A 32-year-old nulliparous woman presents with irregular heavy bleeding. Biopsy shows complex atypical hyperplasia. She wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) High-dose oral medroxyprogesterone therapy

choices.text: Allow trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) with continuous monitoring

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with one prior lower segment cesarean section for non-reassuring fetal heart rate 3 years back; now presents at 38 weeks in early labor. She insists on attempting vaginal birth. Her Bishop score is 7. What is the best course of action?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Allow trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) with continuous monitoring

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman had a complete molar evacuation 2 months ago. Her weekly β-hCG has plateaued over the past 4 weeks, remaining around 800 mIU/mL. Chest X-ray is clear. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Start single-agent chemotherapy with Mtx

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abdominal distension and early satiety. Ultrasound shows a 10 cm solid-cystic adnexal mass with ascites. CA-125 is 680 U/mL. CT suggests no distant metastases. What is the standard next step?

choices.text: Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and suction evacuation
IV antibiotics and wait 48 hours before evacuation

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with fever, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling discharge 4 days after undergoing a medical abortion. She is hypotensive and tachycardic. Uterus is tender. What is the immediate next step?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and suction evacuation

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman develops sudden dyspnea, hypotension, and seizures immediately following a vaginal delivery. There is no history of high BP earlier. She rapidly progresses to cardiac arrest and DIC. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 17-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has tall stature, breast development (Tanner stage IV), but sparse pubic and axillary hair. Her vagina is a blind pouch. On ultrasound, uterus is absent. What is the most likely karyotype?

A 44-year-old woman presents with intermenstrual bleeding and irregular heavy periods. Ultrasound shows a 3.5 cm endometrial polyp and an irregular endometrium. How would this be classified under the FIGO PALM-COEIN system?

A 29-year-old woman delivers vaginally and within minutes complains of severe pain and bleeding. On exam a red mass is seen at the introitus and fundus is not palpable abdominally. What is the most appropriate immediate step?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Manual replacement of uterus

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks has a frank breech presentation. Estimated fetal weight is 3.8 kg. She is in early labor and requests vaginal delivery. What is the best recommendation?

choices.text: Wait and repeat scan in 1 week
Quantitative serum beta-hCG and repeat after 48 hours

questions.text: A woman presents 2 weeks after using levonorgestrel for emergency contraception. Her UPT is positive. She has mild lower abdominal pain. TVS shows no intrauterine sac. What is the best next step?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Quantitative serum beta-hCG and repeat after 48 hours

choices.text: Not recommended until lactation is established

questions.text: A 26-year-old G2P1 woman delivers vaginally without complications. She requests Cu-T insertion before discharge. What is the best time for insertion?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Within 10 minutes of placental delivery

questions.text: A 32y G2 presents to the OPD. She had a previous LSCS 2 years back and is now 37 weeks. She complains of abdominal pain. You check for scar tenderness. Where will you palpate when looking for scar tenderness?
What is being measured in the image shown?

choices.text: 45° away from the pubic symphysis
135° away from the pubic symphysis

questions.text: While doing a PV examination of a 38 weeks primi in labor, you note the following position of the fetus. By how much and in what direction, should internal rotation take place by?
A 32y G2 is undergoing induction of labor using the drug shown in the image for past dates. What does this contain?

choices.text: Need for controlled traction and precise direction

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida at 39+4 weeks of gestation is in the second stage of labor for the past 2.5 hours. She is exhausted and requesting assistance. Fetal heart rate is reassuring. The station is +3, occipito-anterior position, with minimal caput and moulding. The pelvis is adequate. Which of the following factors would most strongly favor vacuum over outlet forceps delivery in this case?

choices.text: Increased peripheral vascular resistance due to estrogen
Decreased plasma volume expansion in early pregnancy
Progesterone-mediated smooth muscle relaxation and nitric oxide vasodilation

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in her second trimester presents for routine antenatal checkup. Her BP is 102/64 mmHg, HR 94/min, and she reports occasional dizziness on standing. Which of the following best explains the drop in blood pressure during early to mid-pregnancy?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Progesterone-mediated smooth muscle relaxation and nitric oxide vasodilation

questions.text: You are shown the placenta of a term neonate after delivery. The image reveals a round, discoid placenta with shiny membranes and centrally inserted umbilical cord. Which of the following best describes this placental morphology?

choices.text: Schedule cesarean section at 37 weeks with manual placental removal
Plan vaginal delivery at 38 weeks with active management of third stage
Schedule cesarean hysterectomy at 34 - 35 weeks with multidisciplinary planning
Attempt conservative management with methotrexate after cesarean to preserve fertility

questions.text: A 36-year-old G5P3L2A1 woman at 33 weeks presents with painless vaginal bleeding. She has a history of 3 previous cesarean sections and one first-trimester curettage. Ultrasound shows anterior placenta previa with numerous irregular lacunae, thinning of the myometrium over the placenta, and loss of the clear zone. Color Doppler reveals increased subplacental vascularity and turbulent flow. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Schedule cesarean hysterectomy at 34 - 35 weeks with multidisciplinary planning

questions.text: A 3-year-old child, accompanied by his parents, visits your clinic for a consultation. Upon observation, it's noted that all family members share a similar short stature, which has been a characteristic trait since birth. The parents express their past experiences of discrimination due to their stature but also acknowledge a shift towards acceptance in society. They wish to prevent their child from facing similar challenges and seek your advice. After conducting a thorough examination, you identify limb shortening and disproportionate short stature in the child, indicative of an inherited defect in enchondral ossification linked to an FGFR3 mutation. You inform the parents that the condition is genetic and explain the limitations regarding its alteration. Based on family history and clinical evaluation, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A newborn becomes lethargic and difficult to feed, developing progressive jaundice with a serum bilirubin level peaking at 13.5 mg/dL. Despite undergoing exchange blood transfusions, the bilirubin levels remain elevated. On the 9th day, vomiting commences, and the infant exhibits hepatomegaly and worsening cerebral symptoms. The accompanying eye findings, consistent with the provided image, and positive urine tests for reducing substances (which are negative when specifically testing for glucose), suggest hereditary galactosemia. Which of the following is not a clinical feature of hereditary galactosemia?

In a primary health center, a 26-year-old woman with an unknown date of her last menstrual period gives birth to a baby weighing 2100 grams. The healthcare team faces the challenge of assessing the newborn's maturity to ensure the provision of appropriate neonatal care. Given the absence of prenatal history for a newborn weighing 2100 grams at birth, which of the following sign should be evaluated by the healthcare team to determine the newborn's gestational maturity?
questions.solution: Ans. D) All of the above

questions.text: Match the following clinical findings with their diagnosis:
questions.solution: Ans. D) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who reports that her son has been suffering from recurrent respiratory infections since infancy. She is concerned because these infections seem to be more severe and frequent compared to his peers. On physical examination, you note a productive cough and auscultate crackles in the lower lobes bilaterally. The child also has a history of chronic ear and sinus infections. You decide to order a chest X-ray, as the report shown below. Given the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, you suspect an autosomal recessive disorder involving a mutation in the dynein protein. Which of the following is not part of the classic triad of this condition?

A 2-month-old male infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to irregular bowel movements, abdominal distension, and bilious vomiting. The mother reports a delayed passage of meconium. Pediatric examination reveals a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves, and a rectal examination shows an empty rectum. An abdominal X-ray demonstrates a dilated colon with a transition zone at the rectosigmoid junction. Considering history and clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Waterson’s shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta
Pott’s shunt: PA is joined to descending aorta
Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery
Pott’s shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a history of cyanotic heart disease is brought to the pediatric surgery outpatient department by their mother. The pediatric surgeon conducts a thorough examination and then engages in a teaching moment with the residents, discussing the various shunt surgeries available for managing such conditions. The surgeon presents several options and asks the residents to identify which statement about shunt surgeries is incorrect, emphasizing the need for precision in understanding and choosing the appropriate surgical intervention.
questions.solution: Ans. D) Pott’s shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-month-old boy with a history of abdominal distension, constipation, and difficulty with urination since birth. On Physical examination a distended abdomen and absence of abdominal muscles was noted. The scrotum was empty along with bilateral undescended testes. The feature of the boy is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

An 8-year-old child is referred to a psychologist by his school due to persistent academic difficulties, particularly in reading and writing. His teacher reports that despite average intelligence and effort, the child struggles to recognize words, confuses letters that look similar, and has difficulty understanding the sounds letters make. Given the child's history of delayed speech, difficulty with phonological awareness, and specific challenges with reading and writing, dyslexia is suspected. Which of the following is a common clinical feature of dyslexia?
Match the following Inclusion bodies and their infectious disease:
questions.solution: Ans. A) A-2, B-4, C-3, D-1

choices.text: Weight for height between -2 and -3 SD
Mid upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 12.2 cm
Weight for height < -3 SD with bilateral pitting edema
Weight for age between -2 and -3 SD

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to your clinic with concerns of poor weight gain and weakness. The child’s mother reports a history of progressive thinness but no fever or diarrhea. On examination, which of the following findings would confirm a diagnosis of Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Weight-for-height < -3 SD with bilateral pitting edema

choices.text: Normal saline at 30 mL/kg over 30 minutes
ReSoMal 10 mL/kg every hour for 4 hours
Ringer's lactate at 15 mL/kg over the first hour
10% dextrose at 10 mL/kg over 30 minutes

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to your clinic with severe acute malnutrition. He appears lethargic with sunken eyes, dry mucous membranes, and delayed skin pinch returning after 2 seconds. His pulse is rapid and thready. You diagnose severe dehydration requiring immediate fluid resuscitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial fluid management for this child?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Ringer's lactate at 15 mL/kg over the first hour

questions.text: In the pediatric ward, a 7-month-old baby has been diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism. As part of an educational exercise, you're discussing the case with a junior colleague, highlighting the clinical features of the condition. To test their understanding, you ask which of the following features is not typically associated with congenital hypothyroidism. How should your colleague respond?

A pediatrician evaluates a 3-month-old infant brought in by the mother due to recurrent infections, persistent diarrhea, and notable skin lesions. Considering the clinical presentation, as shown in the images, which micronutrient deficiency is most commonly associated with these symptoms, and what is the recommended starting dosage for treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Zinc deficiency and 10 mg

choices.text: Mortality in both cases will be less

questions.text: A pediatric resident is presented with two contrasting cases of pediatric patients during their rotation. The resident is asked to assess which case would generally be associated with a higher risk of mortality without intervention. Based on the clinical presentation, which child would typically be at a higher risk of mortality?

In a discussion on the nutritional composition of breast milk, a lactation expert emphasizes the importance of understanding the key nutrients that contribute to infant growth and development. She points out that breast milk contains a predominant carbohydrate that not only serves as a crucial energy source for infants but also aids in the absorption of calcium and other minerals. What is the primary carbohydrate found in breast milk, known for its sweet taste and nutritional benefits?

In a public health seminar on neonatal healthcare in India, a group of healthcare professionals is discussing the critical factors influencing neonatal mortality rates in the country. Amidst the discussion, a junior paediatrician seeks clarification on the primary challenges contributing to neonatal mortality. In the context of neonatal healthcare in India, understanding the leading causes of neonatal mortality is crucial for targeted interventions. Which is the most common cause of neonatal mortality in India?

A 1-year 2 months old child presents with fever and cough. On examination, respiratory rate is noted to be 50 breaths per minute. According to the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria for fast breathing in this age group, what is the appropriate classification?

True about salmon patch?

 

 

  1. It is a hemangioma
  2. Site: Nape of the neck
  3. Common in children
  4. Needs surgical excision

A 28-year-old couple were trying to conceive, they went to the gynaecologist. On further examination, the husband was having tall stature, gynecomastia, small testes, and sparse body hair. Physical examination reveals long limbs and a eunuchoid body shape. Karyotype analysis was advised. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
A 2-year-old child came with complaints of ear, eyes & face abnormalities. The image shown below resembles which triad?
How much time does it take for the finding shown below to appear after BCG vaccination?

choices.text: Observe only as it is mostly physiological jaundice
Liver function tests and liver biopsy as it is mostly due to cholestasis

questions.text: A new-born is noted to have jaundice on the first day of life. The mother's blood type is O positive, and there are no signs of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: A baby born to a mother treated for hypoglycemia

questions.text: Which of the following infants is least likely to develop hypoglycemia?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Appropriate for gestational age (AGA) baby

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and generalized edema. Physical examination reveals sparse, easily pluckable hair, skin changes with hyperpigmented patches that appear to be peeling, and a protuberant abdomen. Her weight is 8 kg. Which of the following laboratory findings would you most expect to find?
